8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:19): need to figure out how to not use "context.beginPath();"  but lines are still anti-aliased
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:19): 8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b: It's not clear what that code is meant to be doing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:20): It sounds like you're calling it each time the user clicks somewhere?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:20): If you don't call beginPath, then every time you call lineTo you're making the current path get longer and longer
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:21): and each time you call stroke() you're re-drawing every line segment that's ever been added to that path
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:21): MikeSmith: am now
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:21): yes it is based o this code: http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.js
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:21): which might be what makes it look non-antialiased (because it's overdrawing the lines)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:21): What you probably want is to do beginPath, and then moveTo with the *previous* mouse coordinates, and then lineTo with the current mouse coordinates
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:22): so that each time you're just drawing a single line between the previous and current mouse positions
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:23): Hmm, that example seems to do it wrong (it never resets so it'll stroke longer and longer paths)
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:24): the weird thing is that drawing works, without "context.beginPath();" but once uncommented, it fails to display
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:24): If you just call beginPath and then lineTo, it's not drawing a line from somewhere to somewhere
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:24): because you've only given it a single point
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:24): which is why you first need to moveTo the previous point
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:26): how would I moveTo previous point?
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:27): was chatting with another developer, and he said he does not even use "context.beginPath();"  to draw lines... how would I be able to do that?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:28): You need to add some global variables and store ev._x and ev._y in them each time you draw, and then use those values in a moveTo the next time you draw (after beginPath and before lineTo)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:29): If you don't use beginPath then you'll never reset to an empty path, so you'll have the problem of repeatedly drawing over the early parts of the path
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:29): (which is an easy mistake because it's hard to notice, but it eventually makes things go really slow and look ugly)
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:29): simply need to anti-alias anything drawn...  what is the best way?
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:31): this is the sample code working, but without anti-aliasing http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:33): It is antialiasing, but it's got this overdraw problem because it never resets the path
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:33): so if you move mouse a hundred times then the first part of the line will have been stroked a hundred times
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:33): and the antialiased grey gets drawn a hundred times and turns black
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:34): which is why it looks aliased
8f86c83f5ef08675a18fb5952b608d6b (20:37): kinda confused...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:39): If you say: ctx.strokeStyle = 'red'; ctx.moveTo(0, 0); ctx.lineTo(100, 0); ctx.stroke(); ctx.strokeStyle = 'green'; ctx.lineTo(100, 100); ctx.stroke();
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:39): then it will stroke the first line segment in red, and then it will stroke *both* line segments in green
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:40): because they're both still part of the current path
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:40): and that's what that example is doing (except it's a lot more than two line segments, and it's stroking them all in black)
